title-group.article-title: S1PR3 mediates inflammatory pain and itch via distinct TRP channel-dependent pathways

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: In this work, we establish a role for the bioactive lipid sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) and its receptor S1PR3 in inflammatory thermal pain and itch. S1P injection elicited robust heat hypersensitivity, acute pain, and itch behaviors in mice, which were wholly dependent on S1PR3. S1P-evoked pain was entirely dependent on TRPV1 ion channels, whereas S1P-evoked itch was dependent on TRPA1. Consistent with our in vivo findings, we found that S1P activated subsets of both heat- and itch-sensitive dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons, and that activation was solely dependent on S1PR3, and not S1PR1. Our data support a model in which S1P elicits neuronal activation via two pathways in distinct subsets of somatosensory neurons. Gβγ-dependent activation of TRPA1 mediates S1PR3-evoked calcium responses in one subpopulation, whereas PLC-dependent activation of TRPV1 mediates S1PR3-evoked calcium responses in the other subpopulation. In the Complete Freund’s Adjuvant (CFA) -induced inflammatory pain model, S1PR3-deficient mice failed to develop heat hypersensitivity, whereas mechanical hypersensitivity developed normally. Pharmacological blockade of S1PR3 activity or S1P production rapidly and selectively ameliorated heat hypersensitivity in wild-type mice treated with CFA. These data definitively identify S1PR3 as a mediator of thermal pain and itch, and, furthermore, demonstrate for the first time that elevated peripheral S1P is an essential driver of chronic inflammatory pain.

sec.title: Significance Statement
sec.p: Chronic pain is a major health problem with few effective treatments. Here, we show that the pro-inflammatory lipid, S1P, and its receptor S1PR3 are essential for thermal hypersensitivity and acute itch. Our results suggest that S1PR3 inhibitors or S1P modulators may be of interest as powerful and heretofore untested treatments for inflammatory pain and itch.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hypersensitivity to thermal and mechanical stimuli is a hallmark of inflammatory pain. During inflammation, immune cells, skin cells, and neurons release a slew of small molecules, lipids, and proteins into the extracellular milieu collectively referred to as the “inflammatory soup” (Ji, Xu, & Gao, 2014). A handful of these factors are known to directly modulate the activity of peripheral sensory neurons, resulting in thermal and/or mechanical hypersensitivity (Chuang et al., 2001; Tominaga, Wada, & Masu, 2001). While several transduction channels and sensory neuronal populations mediating acute pain and itch have been identified (Basbaum, Bautista, Scherrer, & Julius, 2009; Meixiong & Dong, 2017; Pinho-Ribeiro, Verri, & Chiu, 2017), the molecular factors that drive thermal and mechanical hypersensitivity under inflammatory states remains enigmatic (Ghasemlou, Chiu, Julien, & Woolf, 2015). For example, it is known that mice lacking TRPV1 fail to develop thermal but not mechanical sensitization in a model of chronic inflammatory pain (Caterina et al., 2000), yet the physiologically relevant molecular pathways upstream of TRPV1 sensitization are not fully understood. And likewise, while the immune cells that promote mechanical hypersensitivity in chronic inflammatory pain have been identified, the signaling factors that promote that sensitization remain unclear (Ghasemlou et al., 2015).

Sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) is a bioactive sphingolipid associated with asthma, neuropathic pain, inflammatory bowel disease, and psoriasis (Checa et al., 2015; Donoviel et al., 2015; Hou & Fang, 2015; Mysliwiec et al., 2016; Patti et al., 2008; Rivera, Proia, & Olivera, 2008; F. Roviezzo et al., 2015). S1P signaling via S1P Receptor 1 (S1PR1) facilitates the migration, recruitment, and activation of immune cells (Cyster & Schwab, 2012; Matloubian et al., 2004). Intriguingly, expression of both S1PR1 and S1PR3 has been reported in the somatosensory ganglia (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013; Usoskin et al., 2015), and S1P modulates sensory neuronal excitability (Li, Li, Kays, Guerrero, & Nicol, 2015; Wang et al., 2017). However, the role of S1P signaling in somatosensation remain unclear.

In this study, we elucidate the molecular mechanisms of S1P signaling in pain and itch. While the subject of a number of previous studies, whether and how S1P signaling directly mediates acute and inflammatory pain remains enigmatic for several reasons (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013; Canlas et al., 2015; Finley et al., 2013; Janes et al., 2014; Mair et al., 2011; Weth et al., 2015). First, and foremost, the S1P receptors in sensory ganglia involved in S1P-evoked heat hyperalgesia (Mair et al., 2011) and spontaneous pain behaviors (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013) have remained controversial. While both S1PR1 and S1PR3 have been implicated in nociception, the aforementioned studies showed incomplete loss of S1P-evoked behaviors or partial phenotypes. Localization studies were performed with anti-S1P receptor antibodies that stain S1PR3-deficient sensory ganglia. As such, the sensory neuronal subtype(s) that participate in S1P signaling are unknown. Additionally, these studies were cursory and did not probe the downstream signaling pathways activated by S1P receptor(s) in sensory neurons. These studies also employed excessively high concentrations of S1P in behavioral experiments, two to three orders of magnitude higher than levels reported in mammals (0.1 nM – 10 μM), and beyond the solubility limits of this lipid in saline (micromolar). Finally, no study has examined the role of S1P signaling in itch sensation.

Here, we aimed to perform a rigorous and systematic characterization of the behavioral effects and underlying mechanisms of S1P signaling in acute pain and itch and chronic inflammatory pain. We have found that elevated S1P triggers acute pain, heat hypersensitivity, and, surprisingly, itch behaviors that are wholly dependent on S1PR3. Intriguingly, S1PR3-deficient mice do not develop thermal hypersensitivity in the CFA model of inflammatory pain. In addition, acute pharmacological blockade of peripheral S1PR3 signaling or S1P production reverses CFA-evoked thermal hypersensitivity. Our findings define new roles for S1PR3 signaling in pain and itch and show that S1P itself is an essential contributor to inflammatory pain in the periphery.

sec.title: Behavioral studies & mice
sec.p: Sip3mcherry/+ (Sanna et al., 2015) and S1pr3-/- (Kono et al., 2004) mice were obtained from Jackson Laboratory and backcrossed to C57bl6/J, TrpvV-/- and Trpa1-/- mice were described previously (Bautista et al., 2006; Caterina et al., 2000) and Trpv1-/-/Trpa1-/- mice were bred from crossing Trpv1-/+ and Trpa1-/+ mice. Wherever possible, wild-type (for Trpa1 and Trpv1 behavior) or wild-type/heterozygous (S1pr3) littermate controls were used in behavioral experiments. Mice (20–30 g) were housed in 12 h light-dark cycle at 21°C. Mice were singly housed one week prior to all behavioral experiments and were between 8-10 weeks at the time of the experiment. All mice were acclimated in behavioral chambers on the 2 subsequent days for at least 1 hour prior to treatment for itch/pain behavior and radiant heat. Male mice were used for all behavioral studies, due to the effects of the female estrus cycle on itch and pain behaviors.

Itch and acute pain behavioral measurements were performed as previously described (Wilson et al., 2011). Mice were shaved one week prior to itch behavior. Compounds injected: 200 nM, 2 μM, 10 μM S1P (Tocris, Avanti Polar Lipids), 500 μM TY 52156 (Tocris), and 50 μM SKI II (Tocris) in PBS with either DMSO-or Methanol-PBS vehicle controls. Pruritogens were injected using both the neck/rostral back model (20 μl), and the cheek model (20 μl) of itch, as previously described (Wilson et al., 2011). Behavioral scoring was performed while blind to experimental condition and mouse genotype. All scratching and wiping behavior videos were recorded for 1 hour and scored for either the first 30 minutes (scratching) or the first five minutes (wiping). Bout number, time spent scratching, and bout length were recorded for scratching behavior. Wiping was recorded as number of wipes.

For radiant heat hypersensitivity behavior, S1P was injected intradermally into the plantar surface of the hindpaw (20 μl). Radiant heat paw withdrawal latencies, before and after application of compound or vehicle were performed as previously described (Morita et al., 2015; Tsunozaki et al., 2013). Radiant heat assays were performed using the Hargreaves test system (IITC Life Science). Mice were injected with compound of interest into the hind paw, and their paw withdrawal latencies were measured 15 min pre- and 20 min-30 min post-injection. Valid responses for radiant heat included fast paw withdrawal, licking/biting/shaking of the affected paw, or flinching. Mice were allowed to acclimate on platform for 1 hour before injection.

For the CFA model of chronic inflammatory pain, 15 μl of CFA (Sigma-Aldrich) or PBS control was injected into either the left or right hindpaw of 8-9 week old mice briefly anesthetized with 2% isoflurane. Experimenter was blind to genotype. Von Frey paw withdrawal latencies were recorded as previously described (Tsunozaki et al., 2013) using the up-down method (Chaplan, SR, Bach, FW, Pogrel, JW, Chung, JM, Yaksh, 1994; Dixon, 1980) on a mesh grate (IITC Life Science) with calibrated filaments (Touch Test). Radiant heat withdrawal latencies were measured at baseline, 24-, and 48-hours post-injection for both paws. Paw swelling was measured using calipers while experimenter was blind to genotype. Photographs were taken after mice were euthanized using CO2 while photographer was blinded to genotype.

All behavior experiments were carried out using age-matched or littermate cohorts of male mice. Mice were tested in 4-part behavior chambers (IITC Life Science) with opaque dividers (Tap Plastics). Itch and acute pain behavior was filmed from below using high-definition cameras. All experiments were performed under the policies and recommendations of the International Association for the Study of Pain and approved by the University of California, Berkeley Animal Care and Use Committee.

sec.title: Analysis of gene expression vs. itch correlation data
sec.p: A previous study examined the correlation of transcript expression of individual genes in dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons with itch behavior among BXD mouse strains (Morita et al., 2015). One of the top correlated genes from the screen was Fam57b (r = 0.57), a recently identified ceramide synthase (Yamashita-Sugahara et al., 2013) and component of the S1P pathway that is robustly expressed in somatosensory neurons (Gerhold et al., 2013). To assess whether expression of the S1P pathway genes as a group was correlated with somatosensory behaviors across the mouse strains of the BXD population, we first tabulated the absolute value of the Pearson’s correlation r between expression of each S1P pathway gene in turn (Fam57b, Ppargc1a, Spns1, Spns2, Sphk2, S1pr3, S1pr1, Esrrb, Esrrg, Lrp2) and itch behavior (Morita et al., 2015), and calculated the median of these correlation values, rtrue. We then drew 10 random genes from the set of all 16,220 genes with detected expression and computed the median correlation as above using this null set, rnull. Repeating the latter 10,000 times established a null distribution of median correlations; we took the proportion of resampled gene groups that exhibited (rtrue ≥ rnull) as an empirical p-value reporting the significance of enriched correlation between expression and itch in the genes of the S1P pathway.

sec.title: In situ hybridization (ISH)
sec.p: Fresh DRG were dissected from 8-12 week old mice, flash frozen in OCT embedding medium, and sectioned at 14 μm onto slides. ISH was performed using Affymetrix Quantigene ViewISH Tissue 2-plex kit according to manufacturer’s instructions with Type 1 and Type 6 probes. The following probes against mouse mRNAs were created by Affymetrix and used for ISH: S1pr3, Mrgpra3, Trpv1, and Trpa1. Slides were mounted in Fluoromount with No. 1.5 coverglass.Imaging of ISH experiments and all other live- and fixed-cell imaging was performed on an Olympus IX71 microscope with a Lambda LS-xl light source (Sutter Instruments). Images were analyzed using ImageJ software. Briefly, DAPI-positive cells were circled and their fluorescence intensity (AFU) for all channels was plotted against cell size using IgorPro software. Co-labeling analysis was performed using ImageJ. Intensity thresholds were set based on the negative control staining slide. Cells were defined as “co-expressors” if their maximum intensities were greater than the threshold for both the Type 1 and Type 6 probe channels.

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: Cell culture was carried out as previously described (Wilson et al., 2011). Briefly, neurons from dorsal root ganglia of 2-8 week old male and female mice, or trigeminal ganglia from P0-P4 neonates were dissected and incubated for 10 min in 1.4 mg ml–1 Collagenase P (Roche) in Hanks calcium-free balanced salt solution, followed by incubation in 0.25% standard trypsin (vol/vol) -EDTA solution for 2 min with gentle agitation. Cells were then triturated, plated onto Poly D-Lysine coated glass coverslips and used within 20 h. (media: MEM Eagle’s with Earle’s BSS medium, supplemented with 10% horse serum (vol/vol), MEM vitamins, penicillin/streptomycin and L-glutamine).

sec.title: Electrophysiology
sec.p: Current clamp experiments were carried out as previously described (Wilson et al., 2011). Briefly, gap-free current-clamp recordings were collected at 5 kHz and filtered at 2 kHz (Axopatch 200B, pClamp software). Electrode resistance ranged between 1.5-5 MΩ. Internal solution contained 140 mM KCl, 5 mM EGTA and 10 mM HEPES (pH 7.4). Bath solution was physiological Ringer’s solution. The pipette potential was canceled before seal formation. Experiments were carried out only on cells with a series resistance of less than 30 MΩ. Analysis of electrophysiology data was performed in pClamp and IgorPro.

sec.title: Calcium imaging
sec.p: Ca2+ imaging experiments were carried out as previously described (Wilson et al., 2011). DRG neurons from 2-8 week old male and female mice were used for all experiments. Where indicated, TG neurons were from P0-P4 neonates. When experiments were performed on non-wild-type mice, an age-matched wild-type control was also prepared and imaged the same day. Cells were loaded for 60 min at room temperature with 10 μM Fura-2AM supplemented with 0.01% Pluronic F-127 (wt/vol, Life Technologies) in a physiological Ringer’s solution containing (in mM) 140 NaCl, 5 KCl, 10 HEPES, 2 CaCl2, 2 MgCl2 and 10 D-(+)-glucose, pH 7.4. All chemicals were purchased from Sigma. Acquired images were displayed as the ratio of 340 nm/ 380 nm. Cells were identified as neurons by eliciting depolarization with high potassium Ringer’s solution (75 mM) at the end of each experiment. Responding neurons were defined as those having a > 15% increase from baseline ratio. Image analysis and statistics were performed using automated routines in Igor Pro (WaveMetrics). Fura-2 ratios were normalized to the baseline ratio F340/F380 = (Ratio)/(Ratio t = 0).

sec.title: Flow cytometry of CFA-treated paws
sec.p: CFA injections were performed as described above. Briefly, hindpaw skin and underlying fascia of treated and PBS-injected paws were removed from freshly euthanized mice. Skin was placed in RPMI media (Gibco) on ice before mincing with dissection scissors. Digestions were performed for 90 minutes at 37°C on a rotating platform in 1 mL RPMI supplemented with 1:1000 DNaseI enzyme (Roche) and 1 unit LiberaseTM (Roche). Skin was then filtered through 70 μm nylon mesh (Falcon), washed in RPMI, and resuspended in PBS for Aqua Live-Dead staining. Samples were then transferred to FACS buffer (PBS with 0.5% FBS and 2 mM EDTA), blocked, then surface stained with the following antibodies: cKit-Biotin, FceRI-PE, CD49b-PECy7, SiglecF-APC, SA-FITC, Ly6C-PerCP, CD11b-PB, Ly6G-780, CD45.2-AF700.Compensation tubes (single-stain) were prepared for each fluorophore using positive and negative control beads. A spleen from a wild-type animal was also prepared by crushing between frosted glass slides, straining through 70 μm nylon mesh, and lysing of erythrocytes in ACK (Gibco). A portion of spleen sample was heat-killed for 10 minutes at 65°C and stained with Aqua viability stain and set aside. The rest of the spleen was stained normally with the other skin samples. Samples were then run through a flow cytometer (BD Fortessa). Data were analyzed using FlowJo (Prism) and Microsoft Excel. Neutrophils were defined as live single cells with the following staining profile: CD45.2+/CD11b+/Ly6G+/Ly6C+. Inflammatory monocytes were defined as the following: CD45.2+/CD11b+/Ly6G-/Ly6Chigh. Total number of immune cells was reported since neither genotype differed significantly between total number of live cells or total number of CD45.2+ immune cells.

sec.title: Experimental design & statistical analyses
sec.p: All statistical analyses were performed using IgorPro software or Prism. Values are reported as the mean ± SEM where multiple experiments are reported, and mean ± SD where one experiment was performed with multiple wells (for calcium imaging) or mice (for behavior). For comparison between two groups, Student’s unpaired 2-tailed t-test was used. For single-point comparison between > 2 groups, a one-way ANOVA followed by the Sidak’s, Dunnett’s or Tukey’s post hoc tests (where appropriate) were employed. For the time course comparison between 2 groups, 2-way ANOVA was used and single comparison p-values were derived using Sidak’s multiple comparisons. For comparing distributions, a type 2 Kolmogorov-Smirnov test was used. Number of mice or samples required to attain significance was not calculated beforehand and was based on numbers used in similar behavioral studies. Significance was labeled as: n.s., not significant, p ≥ 0.05; *p < 0.05; **p < 0.01 ; ***p < 0.001.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Our group previously harnessed natural variation in somatosensory behaviors among genetically distinct mouse strains to identify candidate transducers in DRG neurons (Morita et al., 2015). Analysis of this dataset revealed the sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) signaling pathway (Fig. 1a) had transcript expression that was significantly correlated with increased itch behaviors (see Methods; p = 0.0116; Fig. 1b). We focused our study on S1PR3 because it was the most highly expressed S1P receptor in the dorsal root ganglia (DRG) (Morita et al., 2015; Usoskin et al., 2015).

caption.title: S1P pathway genes are positively correlated with chloroquine-evoked itch behaviors.
caption.p: a. Tabular list of the top 10 most highly expressed S1P pathway genes in DRG neurons. b. Histogram showing median absolute r-value for gene expression vs. itch plotted against frequency for 10,000 permutations of random subsets of 10 genes in the BXD DRG transcriptome. Red line indicates median r-value for S1P genes (rmedian = 0.399, see Methods).

sec.title: S1PR3 is the sole mediator of acute SIP-evoked pain and itch
sec.p: A handful of previous studies have suggested that S1P may promote acute pain and/or thermal sensitization via various S1PRs in sensory neurons, neutrophils, and/or platelets (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013; Finley et al., 2013; Mair et al., 2011; Weth et al., 2015). Here, we sought to address the specific contribution of S1PR3 signaling to S1P-evoked somatosensory behaviors using physiologically relevant concentrations of S1P (Checa et al., 2015; Myśliwiec et al., 2016; Sanna et al., 2004).

We first used the cheek assay, which allows for simultaneous discrimination of pain-evoked wiping and itch-evoked scratching (Shimada & LaMotte, 2008). We observed that S1P injection resulted in wiping behaviors in response to S1P concentrations at or above 2 μM in the first five minutes after injection (Fig. 2a). We also found that S1P elicited robust scratching behaviors (Fig. 2b) that developed with an average latency of 4 minutes 29 seconds ± 1 minute 37 seconds and persisted for at least 30 minutes. Scratching was elicited in response to a wider range of S1P concentrations than wiping (0.2-10 μM versus 2-10 μM). Furthermore, we did not observe scratching behaviors in response to the lowest tested dose, 50 nM S1P (data not shown). For all subsequent S1P scratching behavioral assays where wiping was not quantified, we injected 0.2 μM S1P into the rostral back and observed an average scratching time of 55.5 ± 7.6 seconds (N = 29 animals), which was significantly greater than scratching evoked by vehicle (0.1% methanol-PBS; 11.1 ± 3.3 seconds, N = 23 animals). Our results from the cheek and rostral back models are consistent with a role for S1P in promoting both acute pain and itch. Consistent with a previous study (Finley et al., 2013), we observed robust heat hypersensitivity after injection of S1P (Fig. 2c). However, the concentration at which we observed hypersensitivity, 10 μM, is at least 20-fold lower than sensitizing or pain-inducing concentrations previously reported in the literature (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013; Finley et al., 2013; Mair et al., 2011). Mechanical hypersensitivity was not observed (data not shown).

caption.title: S1PR3 is the sole mediator of SIP-evoked pain and itch.
caption.p: a. Intradermal cheek injection of 10 μM S1P, 2 μM, 0.2 μM, and 20 μL 0.3% methanol PBS (vehicle), with quantification of number of forepaw wipes over the 5 minute postinjection interval; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(3,8) = 30.67); N = 3 mice per condition). Dunnett’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between treated and vehicle groups. b. For same experiment in (a), quantification of time spent scratching over the 30-minute post-injection interval; p = 0.0027 (one-way ANOVA (F(3,14) = 7.798); N = 3-5 mice per condition). Dunnett’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between treated and vehicle groups. c. Radiant heat normalized paw withdrawal latencies 20-30 minutes post injection of 15 μL 10 μM S1P, 0.2 μM S1P. or 0.3% methanol-PBS vehicle i.d. into the hind paw of wild-type mice; p = 0.0129 (one-way AnOvA (F(2,6) = 9.8); N = 3 mice per condition). Dunnett’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between treated and vehicle groups. d. Number of wipes in response to intradermal injection of 20 μL 10 μM S1P or 0.3% methanol-PBS vehicle in cheek of age-matched S1pr3 +/- and S1pr3 -/-mice; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(3,9) = 40.4); N = 3-4 mice per condition). Dunnett’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between treated and vehicle groups. e. Time spent scratching in response to intradermal injection of 20 μL 0.2 μM S1P or 0.1% methanol-PBS vehicle in rostral back of age-matched S1pr3 +/+ and S1pr3 -/- mice; p = 0.0089 (one-way ANOVA (F(3,9) = 7.274); N = 3-4 mice per treatment). Dunnett’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between treated and vehicle groups. f. Radiant heat normalized paw withdrawal latencies 20-30 minutes post injection of 15 μL 10 μM S1P or 0.3% methanol-PBS vehicle i.d. into the hind paw of age matched S1pr3 +l+ and S1pr3 -/- mice; p = 0.0004 (one-way ANOVA (F(3,32) = 7.964); N = 8-10 mice per condition). Tukey’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between treated and vehicle groups. Unless otherwise indicated, all error bars represent mean ± SD.

sec.p: We next tested the requirement of S1PR3 to S1P-evoked itch and pain behaviors. S1pr3 -/- mice displayed significantly attenuated S1P-evoked scratching indistinguishable from vehicle injection (10.6 ± 12.3 s versus 6.3 ± 6.2 s, respectively; Fig. 2e). S1pr3-/- mice additionally lacked the robust heat hypersensitivity and cheek wiping in response to injection of 10 μM S1P we observed in both S1pr3+/+ and S1pr3+/- littermates (Fig 2d,f). As previously reported, we observed no defects in baseline thermal sensitivity in S1pr3-/- mice. The complete loss of S1P-evoked behaviors in S1PR3-deficient mice suggests that S1PR3 is the sole receptor by which S1P signals in somatosensory neurons to drive heat hypersensitivity, pain, and itch.

sec.title: S1PR3 is expressed and functional in subsets of TRPV1+ thermal nociceptors and TRPA1+ pruriceptors
sec.p: Our acute behavioral data suggest that S1P-evoked behaviors are mediated by activation of thermal nociceptors and pruriceptors. We demonstrated by in situ hybridization (ISH) that 43% of dorsal root ganglion cells express S1pr3. These neurons comprise two main populations: medium-to-large diameter mechanonociceptors as well as small-diameter neurons. Here, in order to address the role of S1PR3 in thermal pain and itch, we characterized the small-diameter S1pr3+ neurons by performing co-ISH of S1pr3 with known markers of C-nociceptor populations. We found that 51% of S1pr3+ cells express Trpv1, 34.3% express Trpa1, and 11.6% express Mrgpra3 (Fig. 3a). These were indeed small-diameter nociceptors and/or pruriceptors (mean diameter of Trpv1+/S1pr3+ cells = 23.4 ± 8.2 μm). In summary, our cellular localization data reveal two main populations of small-diameter S1pr3+ neurons: 1) Trpv1-positive thermal nociceptors and, 2) Trpa1-positive cells, including Mrgpra3+ pruriceptors. These results are consistent with our behavioral studies showing a role for S1PR3 in acute pain and itch.

caption.title: S1PR3 is expressed and functional in subsets of TRPV1+ thermal nociceptors and TRPA1 + pruriceptors.
caption.p: a. Co-ISH of S1pr3 (green) with Trpv1, Trpa1, and Mrgpra3 (magenta) in sectioned whole dorsal root ganglia from adult wild-type mice. Third column: overlay. Scale bar = 100 μm. Images were acquired using a 10x air objective. b. Current-clamp trace of a single neuron firing action potentials in response to bath addition of 1 μM S1P and 1 μM capsaicin. N = 4 of 10 neurons responded to S1P and N = 1 of 1 S1P-responsive also responded to capsaicin. c. (Top) Fura-2 AM calcium imaging before (left) and after (right) addition of 1 μM S1P in S1P3 mCherry/+ cultured mouse DRG neurons. Bar indicates fluorescence ratio. Right-hand image indicates mCherry fluorescence. Arrows indicate an mCherry+/S1P-cell (right) and an mCherry+/S1P- cell (left). d. Percentage of mCherry+ DRG neurons which respond to 1 μM S1P (N = 274 neurons). Error bars represent mean response ± SD. e. Venn diagram demonstrating overlap of neuronal subpopulations activated by capsaicin, AITC, chloroquine, and S1P. Relative proportion of overlap represents % overlap as calculated from ratiometric calcium imaging data (N = 4,000 neurons). f. Effects of 100 μM TY 52156 (p = 0.0016 (two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test (t(6) = 5.42); N = 4 wells of 100 cells each)) or 1 μM W146 (p = 0.7921 (two-tailed unpaired Student’s t-test (t(4) = 0.2817; N = 3 wells of 100 cells each)) on S1P responses of cultured DRG neurons. Error bars represent mean ± SD. g. Percent responders to S1P in age-matched wild-type and S1pr3-/- cultured DRG and TG neurons; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(7,95) = 4.764); N = 2 DRG and 2 TG preparations of 8 wells each). Sidak’s multiple comparisons p-values are represented on graph for comparisons made between genotypes. Error bars represent mean ± SEM.

sec.p: We next employed whole cell current-clamp measurements to test whether S1P was sufficient for action potential firing. Indeed, 1 μM S1P evoked action potential firing in capsaicin-sensitive neurons (Fig. 3b). As an independent strategy to complement our ISH and electrophysiology studies, we employed an S1pr3 mCherry reporter mouse, which produces functional S1PR3-mCherry fusion protein. Using sensory neurons this mouse in ratiometric calcium imaging, we found that 56.1 ± 22.4 % of mCherry-expressing neurons were activated by 1 μM S1P (Fig. 3c-d and these cells had a mean diameter of 22.4 ± 1.0 μm. Furthermore, 51.1 ± 16.8% of capsaicin-responsive neurons were mCherry+, indicating functional overlap with TRPV1+ thermal nociceptors. This suggests that only small-diameter thermal nociceptors and/or pruriceptors are activated by S1P.

Further characterization via calcium imaging in wild-type sensory neurons revealed that 1 μM S1P activates 34.2% of neurons, which fall into two main populations: 22.6% are TRPV1+/TRPA1+ neurons, which are capsaicin- and AITC-sensitive, and 11.6% are TRPV1+/TRPA1- neurons, which are capsaicin-sensitive and AITC-insensitive (Fig. 3e). The complete overlap of S1P-responsive neurons with TRPV1+ neurons suggests a role for S1P in heat hypersensitivity. Previous studies have shown that the MrgprA3+ subpopulation of TRPA1+ neurons are required for many forms of non-histaminergic acute and chronic itch (Han et al., 2013; Wilson et al., 2011). In keeping with our hypothesized role for S1P in itch, 80% of chloroquine-responsive MrgprA3+ neurons responded to S1P. Our findings are consistent with a role for S1P in activation of thermal nociceptors that express TRPV1 and pruriceptors that express TRPA1.

We thus sought to examine the contribution of S1PR3 to S1P-evoked neuronal activation, for which the literature is contradictory and suggestive of contributions of both S1PRs 1 and 3. Incubating cells with the S1PR3-selective antagonist TY 52156 significantly attenuated S1P-evoked calcium transients (Fig. 3f). In contrast, the S1PR1-selective antagonist W146 had no effect on S1P responses (Fig. 3f). Thus, we hypothesized that S1PR3 is required for S1P-evoked calcium signals. In support of our hypothesis, cultured DRG and TG neurons isolated from SlprS-/- mice exhibited no calcium responses to 1 μM S1P, and displayed indistinguishable AITC- and capsaicin-evoked responses compared to wild-type controls (Fig. 3g). These findings show that S1PR3, but not S1PR1, is required for neuronal activation by S1P.

sec.title: S1P activates sensory neurons via distinct TRPV1- and TRPA1-dependent mechanisms.
sec.p: We set out to identify the molecular pathway underlying S1P-evoked calcium transients in cultured mouse DRG sensory neurons. S1P responses were mediated solely by calcium influx, as chelation of extracellular calcium with 10 mM EGTA abolished all responses (Fig. 4a), suggesting that S1P triggers the opening of plasma membrane cation channels. We also observed similar results with application of Ruthenium Red (Fig. 4b), a blocker of a number of calcium-permeable ion channels, including TRP channels.

caption.title: S1P activates sensory neurons via distinct TRPV1- and TRPA1-dependent mechanisms.
caption.p: a. Error bars represent mean ± SD. b. Percent responders for vehicle, 1 μM S1P, AITC, and Cap in vehicle treated and 10 μM Ruthenium Red-treated DRG neurons; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(5,17) = 17.42); N = 5 wells of ∼100 neurons each per treatment). Error bars represent mean ± SD. c. Percent responses for 1 μM S1P in +/+ and Trpv1 -/- neurons; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(7, 179) = 72.67); N = 3 age-matched mice per genotype). Error bars represent mean responses ± SEM. d. Percent responses for 1 μM S1P in +/+ and Trpa1 -/- neurons; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(7,210) = 105); N = 3 age-matched mice per genotype). Error bars represent mean responses ± SEM. e. Dose-response curve of mean neuronal responses to varying concentrations of S1P. Concentrations used: 1, 10, 50, 100, 200, 1000, and 10,000 nanomolar. Error bars represent mean ± SD (N = 2 animals). Black dotted line indicates sigmoidal fit for all S1P responders from which EC50 was derived. Colored traces indicate proportion of neurons responding to S1P and AITC or S1P and capsaicin at indicated concentrations. f. Effect of 50 μM Capsazepine (TRPV1 antagonist) and 50 μM HC-030031 (TRPA1 antagonist) vs. DMSO-Ringer’s vehicle on S1P-evoked calcium responses in cultured DRG neurons; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(8,30) = 84.32); N = 3 wells of ∼100 neurons each per treatment) Error bars represent mean responses ± SD. g. Percent responses for vehicle, 1 μM S1P, AITC, and Cap in Trpa1/Trpv1 +/+ and '/- DRG neurons; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(7,40) = 8.555); N = 2 age-matched mice per genotype) Error bars represent mean ± SD. h. Percent S1P responders as a fraction of total neurons pre-incubated 15 minutes with either DMSO-Ringer’s vehicle, 1 μM U73122 (PLC blocker), or 100 μM Gallein (Gβγ); p = 0.0030 (one-way ANOVA (F(3,8) = 11.32); N = 3 wells of ∼100 neurons each per treatment). Error bars represent mean responses ± SD. Unless otherwise indicated, Sidak’s multiple comparisons were made between treated and vehicle for each agonist.

sec.p: Since TRPA1 and TRPV1 have been shown to mediate GPCR-dependent calcium signaling and activation in small-diameter sensory neurons, we asked whether either of these channels mediated S1P-evoked neuronal activation. We found that the percentage of sensory neurons exhibiting calcium transients in response to S1P application were reduced in neurons isolated from both Trpv1-/- (24.4 ± 5.84% vs. 34.8 ± 6.25%) and Trpa1-/- mice (8.6 ± 4.3% vs. 34.8 ± 3.3%; Fig. 4c-d).

By ratiometric calcium imaging, we observed a dose-dependent increase in the percentage of DRG neurons activated by S1P, with an EC50 of 104 nM and maximal activation at 1 μM (Fig. 4e). However, neurons which were responsive to both AITC and S1P exhibited a slightly lower EC50 for S1P (102 nM), and were activated by lower S1P concentrations (10 nM) than neurons which were responsive to capsaicin and S1P (EC50 : 155 nM). This supports the notion that S1P-evoked neuronal activation via TRPV1 and TRPA1 may occur in different populations of sensory neurons, rather than through A1/V1 crosstalk in the same cells.

We also performed ratiometric calcium imaging on wild-type DRG neurons treated with the TRPV1 antagonist capsazepine (50 μM) or the TRPA1 antagonist HC-030031 (50 μM). HC-030031 significantly reduced S1P responses by ∼78% (HC: 3.673 ± 1.568% vs. Veh: 17 ± 2.19%) whereas capsazepine significantly attenuated S1P responses by only ∼50% (8.69 ± 0.865% vs. 17 ± 2.19%; Fig. 4f). Neurons isolated from mice lacking both TRPA1 and TRPV1 showed S1P responses similar to those evoked by vehicle (Fig. 4g).

We asked whether activation of sensory neurons by S1P/S1PR3 could be due to different G-protein coupled mechanisms in distinct neuronal subpopulations. We found that inhibition of PLC signaling using the drug U73122 blocked 42.4% of S1P-evoked calcium responses, whereas the Gβγ blocker gallein attenuated 73.2% of S1P responses (Fig. 4h). Further experiments showed that gallein and U73122 attenuate calcium responses to S1P in AITC-sensitive neurons (S1P + vehicle: 22% S1P+/AITC+; S1P + Gallein: 6.2% S1P+/AITC+; S1P + U73122: 11.2% S1P+/AITC+) with gallein causing much greater attenuation, whereas U73122 attenuates the majority of responses in capsaicin-sensitive, AITC-insensitive neurons (S1P + vehicle: 14.5% S1P+/CAP+; S1P + U73122: 1.6% S1P+/CAP+). Our results with the G-protein inhibitors mirror our observed proportions of TRPA1+ and TRPA1- S1P-responsive neurons, suggesting that S1PR3 may signal primarily via PLC to activate TRPV1 and via Gβγ and/or PLC to activate TRPA1, similar to the behavior of other excitatory GPCRs that signal via these channels in somatosensory neurons (Imamachi et al., 2009; Morita et al., 2015; Wilson et al., 2011). Overall, our data suggest that S1PR3 signaling opens TRPA1 or TRPV1 channels in two distinct subpopulations of DRG neurons via canonical G-protein coupled mechanisms.

sec.title: S1P elicits pain and itch via distinct molecular pathways
sec.p: We hypothesized that the heat-sensor TRPV1 would be required for S1P-evoked acute pain and heat hypersensitivity; however, we could not predict whether S1P-evoked itch would be transduced via the TRPV1-dependent or TRPA1-dependent itch pathways. To this end, we tested the requirement of TRPA1 and TRPV1 to S1P-evoked itch and pain behaviors. In both the cheek wiping and radiant heat assays, S1P injection elicited robust acute pain and heat hypersensitivity behaviors in wild type and Trpa1-/- mice, but not in Trpv1-/- mice (Fig. 5a,c). Wild-type and Trpv1-/-, but not Trpa1-/- mice, exhibited robust scratching behaviors to S1P that were significantly greater than vehicle (Fig. 5b). Thus we concluded that S1P-evoked spontaneous pain behaviors and heat hypersensitivity are mediated by TRPV1 and that S1P-evoked itch is mediated by TRPA1, a known transducer of acute and chronic itchy stimuli (Wilson et al., 2011, 2013). Overall, our results highlight a key role for S1PR3 signaling through distinct molecular pathways in S1P-evoked acute pain, heat hypersensitivity, and itch.

caption.title: S1P elicits pain and itch via distinct molecular pathways.
caption.p: a. Number of wipes in response to intradermal injection of 20 μL 10 μM S1P or 0.3% methanol-PBS vehicle in cheek of age-matched wild-type, Trpa1 -/- and Trpv1 -/-mice; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(5,11) = 33.98); N = 3 age-matched mice per condition). Error bars represent mean ± SD. b. Time spent scratching in response to intradermal injection of 20 μL 0.2 μM S1P or 0.1% methanol-PBS vehicle in rostral back of age-matched wild-type, Trpa1-/- and Trpv1-/- mice; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(5,91) = 14.13); N = 8 or more age-matched mice per condition). Error bars represent mean ± SD. c. Radiant heat normalized paw withdrawal latencies 20-30 minutes post injection of 15 μM 10 μM S1P or 0.3% methanol-PBS vehicle i.d. into the hind paw of age matched wild-type, Trpa1 -/- and Trpv1 -/- mice; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(5,66) = 31.23); N = 7 or more age-matched mice per condition). Error bars represent mean ± SD. For all graphs, Sidak’s multiple comparisons were made between treated and vehicle for each genotype.

sec.title: S1P and S1PR3 are essential for chronic thermal hypersensitivity
sec.p: The Complete Freund’s Adjuvant (CFA) model of chronic inflammatory hypersensitivity is widely used as a model of peripheral inflammation, but the molecular basis of pain hypersensitivity in this model is incompletely understood. Injection of CFA into the hindpaw causes significant thermal and mechanical hypersensitivity and swelling in wild type animals. In this model, thermal hypersensitivity is dependent on TRPV1 ion channels (Caterina et al., 2000), although the upstream mechanisms of TRPV1 sensitization in CFA are unclear (Boyce et al., 1996). Additionally, paw edema in this model is due to extensive plasma extravasation, in which soluble components of blood plasma are exposed to the skin. S1P, which is present at concentrations 10- to 100-fold higher in blood plasma than in peripheral tissue, presents itself as an attractive but unstudied component of the CFA inflammatory soup.

We therefore explored the role of S1PR3 in the CFA model of inflammatory pain. A variety of immune cells infiltrate into the hindpaw following CFA treatment, and a recent study has shown that myeloid cells are the principal driver of CFA-evoked mechanical but not thermal hypersensitivity (Ghasemlou et al., 2015). Because S1P plays a key role in immune cell migration, we asked whether S1pr3-/- displayed normal CFA-evoked immune cell infiltration into the hindpaw. We observed no difference between Slpr3-/- and +/- animals among all immune cell subtypes quantified (Fig. 6a-b), in support of previous studies showing that S1PR1 is the primary mediator of S1P signaling in immune cells.

caption.title: S1P and S1PR3 are essential for chronic thermal hypersensitivity.

Sidak’s multiple comparisons were made between HET and KO for each cell type. c. (Bottom) Hindpaw swelling of CFA-treated paw compared to PBS-treated paw as measured to the nearest 1 /10th mm 24- and 48- hours post CFA injection; ; pgenotype = 0.0003 (two-way ANOVA (F(1,8) = 9.64); N = 5 mice per genotype). Error bars represent mean ± Sd. e. (Left) Thermal latency assessed before and after CFA injection (arrow) with either vehicle (VEH) or SKI II acutely administered on Day 1; p < 0.0001 (one-way ANOVA (F(2,21= 19.16); N = 5-7 mice per treatment). Dunnett’s test comparisons to baseline are indicated on graph. Error bars represent mean ± SD.

sec.p: We next compared CFA-evoked hypersensitivity between S1pr3+/- and S1pr3-/- littermates, as no significant differences were observed between S1pr3+/+ and S1pr3+/- animals (Fig. 6). Strikingly, S1pr3-/- animals failed to develop heat hypersensitivity (Fig. 6c), and displayed mild attenuation of hindpaw swelling (Fig. 6d), similar to what has been reported for CFA-treated TRPV1-deficient animals (Caterina et al., 2000). We therefore hypothesized that S1P levels become elevated under inflammatory conditions, and that this promotes heat hypersensitivity via S1PR3-mediated sensitization of TRPV1. In support of our hypothesis, acute blockade of S1P production with SKI II (Chiba, Takeuchi, Sakai, & Misawa, 2010) rapidly reversed CFA heat hypersensitivity (Fig. 6e). Furthermore, acute S1PR3 blockade with TY elevated heat-evoked withdrawal latencies to pre-CFA, baseline levels (Fig. 6e). These results demonstrate that peripheral S1P promotes CFA-evoked heat hypersensitivity via S1PR3 signaling and is a component of the inflammatory soup that actively signals to promote pain.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: S1P is a bioactive signaling lipid best known for its essential roles in immune cell migration, maturation, and activation via S1PR1 (Matloubian et al., 2004; Roviezzo et al., 2011; Schwab et al., 2005). Recent studies have linked aberrant S1P signaling to a variety of diseases, including: asthma, multiple sclerosis, cancer, psoriasis, and pain (Brinkmann et al., 2010; Checa et al., 2015; Liang et al., 2013; Myśliwiec et al., 2016; Patti et al., 2008; Rivera et al., 2008; F. Roviezzo et al., 2015). Yet the cellular and molecular targets of S1P in these disorders are largely unknown. Here, we show that S1PR3 is the sole mediator of S1P-evoked pain and itch and that S1P signaling is essential to chronic heat hypersensitivity (Fig. 7a), highlighting the potential for a direct contribution of S1P to sensitization, pain and/or itch in these diseases.

caption.title: Model of the effects of elevated S1P on S1PR3-dependent thermal hypersensitivity and acute itch in sensory neurons.
caption.p: a. Elevated S1P can 1) elicit thermal hypersensitivity or acute pain via S1PR3-dependent activation of TRPV1 (top) and 2) elicit itch-evoked scratching via S1PR3-dependent activation of TRPA1.

sec.title: S1P evokes pain and itch via S1PR3
sec.p: The role of S1P in acute pain and pain hypersensitivity has been controversial. There are conflicting reports of whether S1P mediates acute flinching and licking pain behaviors, and/or thermal and mechanical hypersensitivity (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013; Finley et al., 2013; Mair et al., 2011; Weth et al., 2015). Likewise, these previous studies employed high-micromolar or millimolar concentrations of S1P in mouse behavioral experiments, leaving it unclear whether physiologically relevant S1P levels could contribute to somatosensation. Here we have shown that physiological levels of S1P (nanomolar to low micromolar) are sufficient to evoke somatosensory behaviors. We demonstrate that S1P triggers acute pain and heat hypersensitivity via the noxious heat-sensing ion channel TRPV1. Additionally, S1P promotes itch-evoked scratching that is dependent on the irritant-sensing ion channel TRPA1. While a number of previous studies have implicated both S1PR1 and 3 in somatosensory neuron function (Camprubi-Robles et al., 2013; Mair et al., 2011), several lines of evidence unequivocally show that S1PR3 is the sole mediator of S1P-evoked pain and itch. First, DRG neurons isolated from S1PR3-deficient animals do not respond to S1P. Second, application of an S1PR3-selective antagonist, but not an S1PR1-selective antagonist, attenuates S1P responses in cultured DRG neurons. Finally, S1PR3-deficient mice display no S1P-evoked scratching, wiping, or heat hypersensitivity.

We also show for the first time that S1P acts as a pruritogen to evoke acute itch. Recent studies have shown that circulating S1P levels are increased in chronic itch patients (from ∼0.1 to 2 μM in healthy versus chronic itch patients; Checa et al., 2015; Myśliwiec et al., 2016). S1PR3-deficient mice displayed a complete loss of S1P-evoked itch behaviors. Future studies will explore the role of S1P/S1PR3 signaling in chronic itch models to ascertain the pathological relevance of S1P-evoked itch.

sec.title: S1PR3 mediates inflammatory thermal pain
sec.p: In the CFA model of inflammatory pain, both mechanical and thermal hypersensitivity occur with distinct time courses, suggesting differential modes of regulation (Ghasemlou et al., 2015). It is well-established that TRPV1 is required for CFA-evoked thermal hypersensitivity (Caterina et al., 2000). We now show that S1PR3 activation can lead to opening of TRPV1 channels, and that both S1PR3 and elevated S1P are required for CFA-evoked thermal hypersensitivity. These data suggest that S1P may be an important contributor to inflammatory pain. Consistent with this hypothesis, S1PR3-deficient mice display partial attenuation of paw swelling, a hallmark of neurogenic inflammation, but still develop mechanical hypersensitivity, which has been previously been shown to depend on infiltration of myeloid cells which display normal infiltration in the S1PR3 knockout animals. S1PR3 signaling in neurons may generally contribute to pain under inflammatory conditions. Plasma extravasation and edema, common symptoms of inflammation, may increase local S1P concentrations and contribute to sensitization. Moreover, we use pharmacology to show that active S1P signaling is required to maintain chronic heat hypersensitivity.

Our findings suggest sensory neuronal S1PR3 may play roles in a host of disorders linked to S1P signaling. Although S1P is produced by nearly every cell type, blood plasma contains the highest levels of S1P (low micromolar), and S1P is secreted in large amounts by activated mast cells (Olivera, Allende, & Proia, 2013; F. Roviezzo et al., 2015). Others have shown that sensory neurons innervating the lung express S1pr3 and that administration of a non-selective S1P receptor agonist can enhance asthma-like airway hyperreactivity after acetylcholine challenge (Trankner, Hahne, Sugino, Hoon, & Zuker, 2014). It is also well known that TRPV1 + sensory afferents are required for airway hypersensitivity (Rogerio, Andrade, & Calixto, 2011). Furthermore, mast cells, which release S1P when activated (Kalesnikoff & Galli, 2008), play important roles in allergic asthma as well as itch, and we propose that S1PR3 may play an important role in mediating itch and/or airway hyperreactivity under these conditions.

Several S1PR modulators are currently in clinical trial for diseases linked to pain and/or itch, including multiple sclerosis, IBD, and psoriasis (Brinkmann et al., 2010; Degagné & Saba, 2014; Kunkel, Maceyka, Milstien, & Spiegel, 2013). While these drugs are intended to target the immune system, we propose neuronal S1P/S1PR3 signaling as a potential target for the treatment of inflammatory pain and itch.
